channel.title: Golang Weekly
channel.description: A weekly newsletter about the Go programming language

item.title: ã€Go 1.25's flight recorderã€‘å»1.25çš„é£è¡Œè®°å½•å‘˜
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹572 â€” October 1, 2025

Read the WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

Flight Recorder in Go 1.25 â€” Billed as â€œa powerful new tool in the Go diagnostics toolboxâ€, the â€˜flight recorderâ€™ continuously collects execution traces and buffers the past few seconds, letting you capture exactly the window of time needed to diagnose a problem after itâ€™s alreadyÂ happened.

Carlos Amedee and Michael Knyszek

Cloud Infrastructure: Startup toÂ Scale â€” Deploy and scale apps with containers, Supabase, AWS, Terraform, and CI/CD pipelines. Go from startup speed to enterprise-grade reliability through the three phases of growth: Startup, Growth, andÂ Scale.

Frontend Masters sponsor

Accepted! Go Proposals Distilled â€” A new series of blog posts covering accepted Go language proposals â€” so you can get up to speed with things coming to future versions of Go without having to read the entire proposal. So far Anton has covered maphash.Hasher and new(expr).

Anton Zhiyanov

IN BRIEF:

  • The Traefik project celebrates its tenth anniversary with a look at how it's matured, grown, and become one of the best known Go-powered infrastructure tools.

  • JetBrains offers a preview of its new Islands theme coming to its IDEs, including GoLand â€“ you can try it now, however.

ğŸ“ŠÂ 'We Tried Go's Experimental Green Tea Garbage Collector and It Didn't Help Performance' â€” For Doltâ€™s use case (which is quite specific), the experimental â€˜Green Teaâ€™ garbage collector you can opt to use in Go 1.25 provided no real benefits, but your mileage may vary so itâ€™s worth tryingÂ out.

Zach Mushrave (Dolt)

Starving, Sleeping, and Yielding: Understanding Go's Scheduler â€” â€œWriting concurrent programs in Go is easy, but understanding the behaviour (or, more frequently, misbehaviour) of those programs is anotherÂ matter.â€

John Arundel

3 Critical TTL Patterns for In-Memory Caching â€” Leaning on the authorâ€™s own Hot library that provides fast in-memory caching for GoÂ apps.

Samuel Berthe

âš¡ Supercharge Postgres: 2PB Scale & 1.5t Metrics/Day â€” TigerData makes Postgres the fastest database for modern workloads: 2PB scale, 1.5T metrics/day, no blackÂ boxes.

TigerData sponsor

ğŸ“º OpenCV for Go and WebAssembly with Ron Evans â€“ A live 90-minute session about computer vision with Ron Evans (of TinyGo and GoCVÂ fame). OpenCV Live

ğŸ“„ The new() Function Will Take an Expression in GoÂ 1.26 Chris Siebenmann

ğŸ“„ Build a Water Simulation in Go with raylib-go Tim Little

ğŸ“„ Register Allocation in the Go Compiler Vladimir Makarov

ğŸ“„ Slice Tails Don't Grow Forever Ted Unangst

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

Do 2.0: Type-Safe Dependency Injection Toolkit â€” A library that provides the dependency injection design pattern and uses generics instead of reflection in order to provide a type-safe API. If youâ€™re already a Do user, thereâ€™s a guide for upgrading from v1.x to v2.0 to follow. GitHubÂ repo.

Samuel Berthe

Failsafe: Fault Tolerance, Resilience Patterns & Policies â€” A library for building fault-tolerant apps where you can wrap code in various resilience policies such as Retry, CircuitBreaker, RateLimiter, Timeout, and Fallback. Releases in recent weeks add several new features including usage tracking (to enforce fairness) and execution budgets for setting a maximum â€˜budgetâ€™ for retries or hedges across aÂ system.

Jonathan Halterman

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

ğŸ Tuple - how developers at Shopify, Figma, and Stripe collaborate on code. Stop dictating and take control withÂ Tuple.

PegoMock 4.3: A Powerful Yet Simple Mocking Framework â€” Brings an easy-to-read DSL to mocking. You can do stubbing and argument matching, asÂ well.

Peter GÃ¶tz

eBPF Web Fingerprint: Library and Server for TCP and TLSÂ Fingerprinting
Alberto Ventafridda

  • ğŸ©» dicom 1.1 â€“ DICOM medical image parsing library and CLIÂ tool.

  • Open Policy Agent (OPA) 1.9 â€“ General-purpose policy engine.

  • MCP-Go 0.41 â€“ An implementation of the Model Context ProtocolÂ (MCP) for integrating with AIÂ apps.

  • Fiber 3.0.0 RC2 â€“ Express.js-inspired Web framework forÂ Go.

  • Shiori 1.8 â€“ Simple bookmark manager app.

ã€‘

item.title: ã€The talks from GopherCon UK 2025 go liveã€‘Gophercon UK 2025çš„ä¼šè°ˆGo Live
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹571 â€” September 24, 2025

Read the WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

Go's Support for Valgrind Instrumentation â€” Valgrind is a commonly used instrumentation framework for creating tools that can do profiling and detect various memory management and threading bugs in apps. This still-experimental support for Valgrind in Go opens up a wealth of extra opportunities for low-level diagnostics for GoÂ programs.

Roland Shoemaker

ğŸ’¡ This Hacker News discussion has more details, including a comment from the author of the pull request/CL about what the support was initially intendedÂ for.

Go Event-Driven: From the Watermill Creators â€” MiÅ‚osz and Robert from Three Dots Labs are launching the next edition of their hands-on training. It teaches the tricky parts of event-driven systems such as the outbox pattern, message ordering, and sagas. Don't sleep on this one. Opens autumnÂ 2025.

Three Dots Labs sponsor

â–¶Â Â Twenty Talks from GopherCon UK 2025 â€” A YouTube playlist containing the just-uploaded talks from last monthâ€™s London-based Go conference. Every talk is technical and deep, but you might particularly enjoy Daniel Martiâ€™s Whatâ€™s Coming in Go 1.25, Roland Shoemaker talking about Go security, or Emily Achieng talking about Go module hygiene and keeping your go.sum and go.mod files inÂ check.

GopherCon UK

Practical Networking Patterns in Go â€” A new section of the on-going â€œGo Optimization Guideâ€ featuring 13 guides to the various topics involved in building scalable, networked Go apps â€” including benchmarking, how to achieve â€˜massive concurrencyâ€™, diagnostics, transport protocols, low-level tuning, andÂ more.

Alexander Stavonin

IN BRIEF:

  • The latest Go developer survey is open for just one more week, closing next Tuesday, September 30. You can take it here.

  • WebAssembly/WASM is an increasingly common compilation target for Go, so it's neat to see the WebAssembly 3.0 standard is now 'live' (and already ships with most browsers) with various features that should improve interoperability in the long-term, including garbage collection, tail calls, and exception handling.

  • The IEEE has published a list of the top 'programming languages' in 2025 with Go coming in at numberÂ 10.

Building Conwayâ€™s Game of Life with raylib-go â€” Just a bit of fun. Hereâ€™s the resultingÂ code.

Tim Little

Kubernetes CPU Limits and Go â€” An update of an article from 2024. Goâ€™s runtime doesnâ€™t inherently know that itâ€™s running within a Kubernetes environment, so there are tweaks you can make. However, also bear in mind Go 1.25â€™s changes to GOMAXPROCSâ€™sÂ defaults.

William Kennedy

ğŸ“„ How Fast is Go? Simulating Millions of Particles on a Smart TV â€“ â€œGo is able to simulate 2.5 million particles at 60 fps while sending data at 30 fps to in theory over 300 clients, maybe even aÂ thousand.â€ David Gerrells

ğŸ“„ Making a Cross-Platform Game using Pion and WebRTC Datachannels â€“ The current setup has some drawbacks, but thereâ€™s a lot of potential here if you want to exploreÂ it. Srayan Jana

ğŸ“„ CSRF Protection via Headers in Go 1.25 Jon Calhoun

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

ğŸ¤–Â GoMLX: An Accelerated Machine Learning Framework for Go â€” A set of machine learning libraries and tools designed to act as a sort-of Go alternative to PyTorch or TensorFlow. Despite the name, itâ€™s not related to Appleâ€™s MLX framework and is actually Linux-only for now. It does, however, open up the opportunity to train and use ML models directly from Go, as Eli Bendersky explains in this introductoryÂ post.

GoMLX Team

TableWriter 1.1: Render Rich Text-Based Tables â€” A flexible library for rendering tabular data to ASCII, Unicode, Markdown, HTML, or for colorized terminals. The README is packed withÂ examples.

Oleku Konko

Secure Your Agentic Apps with Auth for GenAI â€” Secure your agentic apps with features like User Authentication for AI agents, Token Vault, and more with Auth0â€™s Auth for GenAI (exclusively in DeveloperÂ Preview).

Auth0 sponsor

Gojekyll: A Fast Go Implementation of Jekyll â€” Jekyll is a very popular Ruby-powered static site generator â€“ this is a â€˜partially-compatibleâ€™ clone that boasts enhanced performance and portability by being written inÂ Go. Worth a look if you have a Jekyll-powered site but want to remove Ruby from yourÂ stack.

Oliver Steele and Daniil Gentili

Valgo 0.7: An Expressive Validator Library â€” Type-safe and extensible validator library built upon generics. Rules are written in functions and not in struct tags. v0.7 adds new validation helpers and type-safe validators that remove codegen and width-specificÂ types.

Cohesive Stack

Fibratus: Windows Kernel Exploration and Observability Tool â€” Now pitched as a â€œadversary tradecraft detection, protection, and huntingâ€ tool, Fibratus captures system events, such as file I/O and network requests, and scans memory, so you can gain insight into what apps are up to. GitHubÂ repo.

Fibratus

Go Allocations Explorer Extension for VSCode â€” Uses your benchmarks to identify and list the allocations inside VSÂ Code.

Matt Sherman

  • purego 0.9 â€“ Library for calling C functions from Go without Cgo, now with support for Objective-C blocks and linux/loong64.

  • k6 1.3 â€“ Modern Go + JavaScript-powered load testing tool.Â (Homepage.)

  • MCP-Go 0.40 â€“ An implementation of the Model Context ProtocolÂ (MCP).

  • NATS.go 1.46 â€“ Go client for the NATS messagingÂ system.

  • BillionMail 4.5 â€“ Go-powered email campaignÂ platform.

  • golangci-lint 2.5 â€“ A faster way to run GoÂ linters.

  • go-github 75.0 â€“ GitHub v3 API clientÂ library.

  • Gin 1.11 â€“ Popular HTTP webÂ framework.

ã€‘
>>>>>>>>>
é˜…è¯»Webç‰ˆæœ¬

Go's Support for Valgrind Instrumentation â€” Valgrind is a commonly used instrumentation framework for creating tools that can do profiling and detect various memory management and threading bugs in apps.å¯¹Valgrindçš„è¿™ç§ä»ç„¶æœ‰å®éªŒçš„æ”¯æŒä¸ºGOè®¡â€‹â€‹åˆ’æä¾›äº†è®¸å¤šé¢å¤–çš„æœºä¼šã€‚

  • IEEEå‘å¸ƒäº†

item.title: ã€The latest Go developer survey is openã€‘æœ€æ–°çš„GOå¼€å‘äººå‘˜è°ƒæŸ¥å¼€æ”¾
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹570 â€” September 17, 2025

Read the WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

Memory Allocation in Go â€” The efficient allocation and management of memory is a fundamental part of what makes Go programs reliable and responsive and, luckily, Go abstracts away most of the complexity. If you want to know whatâ€™s going on under the hood, though, this is a fantastic, rich, diagrammedÂ exploration.

Nghia Nguyen

Go Beyond with Frontend and Fullstack Engineering Courses â€” Get $100 off an annual Frontend Masters membership, and gain access to professional courses on Go, TypeScript, Cloud Infrastructure, AWS, React, and much much more. Sale ends soonÂ â†’

Frontend Masters sponsor

It's Survey Time! The 2025 Go Developer Survey is Live â€” Every now and then the Go team seeks input from the community to know what to focus on next. The deadline this time is quite short with the survey closing on September 30, so check it outÂ now.

Todd Kulesza and the Go team

IN BRIEF:

  • Next week (Sep 22-26) is one of Go's 'quiet weeks', a period where the Go team largely goes silent, takes a break, or focuses on deep work withoutÂ interruption. Not a good week for any new language proposals!

  • GitHub's Dependabot now supports Go modules hosted on private registries. Blake Gentry explains more, including why this matters.

GopherCon 2025 Go Contributor Summit Notes â€” Numerous Go contributors came together at the recent GopherCon event to discuss issues including dependency management, the language proposal process, cgo performance, WebAuthn, fuzzing and coverage, WebAssembly as a target (and even the JVM-briefly!), and more. The notes are rough, but flesh out the thinking in manyÂ areas.

Google Docs

The Day the Linter Broke My Code â€” Linters donâ€™t always have all the context when they identify an issue, resulting in cases where an innocuous fix can break your code, forcing you to.. lint yourÂ linter?

Oliver Eikemeier

Product for Engineers Newsletter â€” Build better products, not just better code. Learn how to build features users love. Subscribe forÂ free.

PostHog sponsor

ğŸ“„ Using Go Channels to Solve Interface Impedance Mismatch â€“ â€œone of the few times in years of Go development that Iâ€™ve used channels â€¦ for a non-concurrent useÂ caseâ€ Zach Musgrave

ğŸ“„ How to Implement the Outbox Pattern in Go and Postgres â€“ A resilient way to ensure messages get to where theyâ€™re meantÂ to. Alex Pliutau

ğŸ“„ Building a Simple Stack-Based Virtual Machine in Go â€“ Hereâ€™s theÂ code. Phakorn Kiong

ğŸ“„ Observe Live SQL Queries in Go with DTrace Philippe Gaultier

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

Flaggy 1.6: Idiomatic Go Command Line Input Parsing â€” Supports subcommands, positional values, and flags at any position. No external dependencies and doesnâ€™t insist on a particular project or package layout. v1.6 adds built-in bash/zsh completion generators and drops support for comma separated multi-valueÂ arguments.

Eric Greer

graphics.gd: Use Go with the Godot Game Engine â€” Godot is a popular engine for both 2D and 3D games and, despite the name, isnâ€™t related to Go. This project, however, offers a Go runtime and tooling layer on top of Godot and it can now even be used to create iOS apps inÂ Go.

Quentin Quaadgras

koanf 2.3: Read Configuration with Multiple Sources and Formats â€” Support for JSON, TOML, YAML, environment variables, command line, file, S3 etc. A â€˜lighterâ€™ alternative toÂ Viper.

Kailash Nadh

  • Google Gen AI Go SDK v1.25.0 â€“ Go SDK for integrating Google's generative AI models including Gemini and Vertex AI into applications.

  • FastHTTP 1.66 â€“ Performance-oriented alternative to net/http for specific high-volumeÂ scenarios.

  • PSQL Wire Protocol v0.15.0 â€“ Pure Go implementation of the Postgres server wire protocol for building custom servers.

  • easyjson 0.9.1 â€“ Marshal/unmarshal structs to/from JSON sansÂ reflection.

  • OpenFGA 1.10 â€“ Google Zanzibar-inspired authorizationÂ engine.

  • River 0.25 â€“ Robust job processing system for Go andÂ Postgres.

  • Hugo 0.150.0 â€“ The popular static siteÂ generator.

  • Goyave 5.9 â€“ Opinionated REST API framework.

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

Go beyond caching. Redis 8.2 handles 5x more data with 150 new commands and 8 new data structures vs 7.2. Get startedÂ today.

ğŸ’¬ A Blast from the Past

Retro AIM Server: A Way to Get AIM and ICQ Working Again? â€” A curious Go-powered project that provides a self-hosted instant messaging server that classic AOL Instant Messenger and ICQ clients canÂ use. Why? WhyÂ not?

mk6i

ã€‘
>>>>>>>>>
é˜…è¯»Webç‰ˆæœ¬

ğŸ› ä»£ç å’Œå·¥å…·

- æ”¯æŒä»»ä½•ä½ç½®çš„å­å‘½ä»¤ï¼Œä½ç½®å€¼å’Œæ ‡å¿—ã€‚æ²¡æœ‰å¤–éƒ¨ä¾èµ–æ€§ï¼Œä¹Ÿä¸åšæŒç‰¹å®šçš„é¡¹ç›®æˆ–è½¯ä»¶åŒ…å¸ƒå±€ã€‚ v1.6 æ·»åŠ äº†å†…ç½®çš„bash/zshå¡«å……å‘ç”µæœºï¼Œå¹¶ä¸¢å¼ƒå¯¹é€—å·åˆ†éš”çš„å¤šåŠŸèƒ½å‚æ•°çš„æ”¯æŒã€‚

Eric Greer

- godot æ˜¯2då’Œ3dæ¸¸æˆçš„æµè¡Œå¼•æ“ï¼Œå°½ç®¡åç§°ä¸ nameï¼Œ ä¸ç›¸å…³ã€‚ä½†æ˜¯ï¼Œè¿™ä¸ªé¡¹ç›®åœ¨Godoté¡¶éƒ¨æä¾›äº†è¿è¡Œæ—¶å’Œå·¥å…·å±‚ï¼Œç°åœ¨å¯ä»¥ç”šè‡³å¯ä»¥ä½¿ç”¨åœ¨Goä¸­åˆ›å»ºiOSåº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºã€‚

Quentin Quaadgras

- æ”¯æŒJSONï¼ŒTOMLï¼ŒYAMLï¼Œç¯å¢ƒå˜é‡ï¼Œå‘½ä»¤è¡Œï¼Œæ–‡ä»¶ï¼ŒS3ç­‰ã€‚

kailash nadh

item.title: ã€Making the Go module proxy happier using a LICENSE fileã€‘ä½¿ç”¨è®¸å¯è¯æ–‡ä»¶ä½¿GOæ¨¡å—ä»£ç†æ›´å¿«ä¹
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹569 â€” September 10, 2025

Read the WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

Let's Look at Go's New Experimental API for JSON â€” Working with the Internetâ€™s most popular data exchange format is a fundamental, day-to-day task for most developers but Goâ€™s original json package had enough shortcomings to warrant an attempt at a â€˜v2â€™ which you can use, in experimental form, in Go 1.25. The Go team breaks down the entire story and the behavior of v2 here, but also seeks yourÂ feedback.

Tsai, MartÃ­, et al.

ğŸ’¡ Anton Zhiyanov has a more code-driven tour of what json/v2 offersÂ here.

Go with the Domain: DDD & Clean Architecture inÂ Go â€” For Go developers tired of enterprise patterns that don't fit. The Watermill creators show how DDD actually works in Go with code examples from a realÂ application.

Three Dots Labs sponsor

What the Go Proxy Has Been Doing â€” A few weeks ago, Ted asked What is the Go (module) proxy even doing? after he found it hammering his server. Heâ€™s since traded some emails with Russ Cox and discovered some curious things about the proxyâ€™s behavior, particularly around the contents (and/or lack of) of LICENSE files. This post from Russ Cox himself goes into even moreÂ detail.

Ted Unangst

IN BRIEF:

  • The YAML project, official maintainer of the YAML format, has forked and taken over maintenance of the yaml package.

  • ğŸ˜± Geoffrey Huntley had a single goal: force Claude Code to loop over and over till it built a 'Go like' language based around Gen Z slang, and so Cursed was born. It works, and can even compile to native binaries withÂ LLVM.

  • ğŸ¥ gocv-to-webrtc offers a demonstration of streaming live webcam video to a browser using GoCV for capture, FFmpeg for realâ€‘time encoding, and Pion WebRTC for transport.

Avoiding Common sync.WaitGroup Mistakes â€” WaitGroup is easy to misuse, but as of Go 1.25, the go vet tool has extra checks to prevent error-prone calls to WaitGroup.Add, and WaitGroup.Go helps avoid some problemsÂ altogether.

Jon Calhoun

Solve Go Bugs and Bottlenecks Quickly with AppSignal â€” Fix Go bugs and bottlenecks fast with AppSignal. Get clear insights and ship reliable code. Start your free trialÂ today.
